awd_titl_txt: CIF:  Medium:  Energy-Efficient Encoding of Information
awd_abstract_narration:
The wireless revolution in communication and computing has imbued electrical engineers with a steadily deepening appreciation for the importance of energy-efficient design. On the other hand, energy efficiency has for eons been a paramount consideration of living systems. 

Statistical thermodynamics says that kTln2 is a lower bound for how many joules of energy must be expended in order either to encode/transmit/decode or to write/read/erase one bit of information in an environment at T degrees Kelvin, k being Boltzmann's constant. Biological encoding and decoding that performs close to the thermodynamic limit uses continuous time differential pulse position modulation (CTDPPM), arguably the most energy-efficient way to encode and transmit information. The co-PIs are applying their interdisciplinary expertise in neuroscience and information theory to address research topics such as: (i) Performance trade-offs in their bits/joule maximizing exact solution of a 1915 model by Schrodinger now known to be applicable to thresholding neurons, (ii) Extension of the Schrodinger-style optimization to short term dynamics of bits/joule maximizing CTDPPM systems; the present solution provides statistically optimum behavior only in the long term, (iii) Steps toward extension to networks containing multi-compartment elements, emphasizing hierarchical architectures with feedback governing short-term distribution of energy resources, and (iv) Intriguing connections with the burgeoning research discipline of network coding.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the project is to understand neural computation from a biological perspective. In particular, evolution through natural selection (Nature) has produced microscopic and subsystem optimizations. Identification of such optimizations in the context of neuronal function, identifies and interprets neural computation from the perspective of Nature.

 

The primary optimization studied is the transformation a neuron makes from its input activations to its output activations (neuronal spikes). In contrast to much of signal processing and electrical engineering Nature does not optimize information rates (bits/sec); rather it optimizes information in an energy efficient manner, bits/joule. The energetically optimal code is an interpulse interval (IPI) code. Combining this with the most basic idea of a neuron, it adds up its inputs and produces a pulse out when threshold is reached, leads to the determination of the optimal probability distribution of the IPI code. This probability distribution is determined by its synaptic and communication energy budget: The more energy available the better a neuron performs its estimation problem. Better estimation implies minimum mean squared error for a given energy-budget. Surprisingly, if one also assumes unbiased estimation by a neuron, then the both the prior and the posterior distributions are inferred and the neuron's function can be interpreted as a Bayesian inference.

Biophysical simulations of a well-studied neuron of prefrontal cortex, verifies the fundamental assumption that a neuron can translate its input excitation, via linear summation, into an IPI code.

Additional research studies the energy-efficiency of neuron construction versus performance. That is, brain development is often accompanied by synapse overproduction. We perform simulations demonstrating the advantageous nature of modest synapse overproduction. Basically it saves time to develop useful connections,  which is energy-saving for the mother.
